title: What are GAAP Principles?
description: Learn the fundamental accounting principles that guide financial reporting

words.fact: Relevance is a key qualitative characteristic of useful financial information. Information is relevant when it can influence the economic decisions of users by helping them evaluate past, present, or future events. Relevant information has predictive value, confirmatory value, or both.

Reliability means financial information is free from material error and bias, and faithfully represents what it purports to represent. Reliable information can be depended upon by users to make informed decisions. It requires completeness, neutrality, and freedom from error.

Consistency requires companies to use the same accounting methods from period to period. This allows users to compare financial statements across different time periods and identify trends. Changes in accounting methods must be disclosed and justified.

Materiality refers to the significance of financial information. Information is material if its omission or misstatement could influence the economic decisions of users. The concept helps accountants determine what information must be disclosed in financial statements.

Conservatism (or prudence) principle states that when faced with uncertainty, accountants should exercise caution and not overstate assets or income. This means recognizing expenses and liabilities as soon as possible, but only recognizing revenues when they are assured.

The disclosure principle requires that financial statements include all information necessary for users to make informed decisions. This includes notes to financial statements explaining accounting policies, contingent liabilities, and other relevant information not apparent from the statements themselves.
